newsitem.title: ITALY: Germany's Kohl says 1999 EMU start "unbreakable".
newsitem.headline: Germany's Kohl says 1999 EMU start "unbreakable".

text.p: German Chancellor Helmut Kohl said in an article published in Italy on Thursday that a European single currency should be launched in 1999 as planned and said the commitment to start on that date was "unbreakable".

"We are in favour of a start to Economic and Monetary Union on January 1, 1999, as laid down in the (Maastricht) Treaty," Kohl said in an article published in La Repubblica on the eve of an Italo-German summit in Bonn on Friday.
"The date and the respect for the convergence criteria are unbreakable. We want together a stable euro," Kohl said.
He said a decision on who would take part in EMU at the start would be made in spring 1998 on the basis of 1997 data.

Italy roundly rejected a report in Wednesday's Financial Times that European Union monetary officials were working on a plan to defer Italy's entry until 2000 or 2001. Italy has said it is determined to be ready to join on January 1, 1999.
But German public opinion is loath to give up its strong mark and there are fears that countries like Italy with more erratic economic track records could weaken the common currency.
Kohl said that because the aim was to have a strong euro, any proposals for a loosening of the parameters or a devaluation inside the European Monetary System were damaging.
